jacaetev wrote:

> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Andrew Forward <aforward@g...> wrote:
>  > Use composition as opposed to inheritance.
>  >
>  > public void testSpecific()
>  > {
>  >   testCommon();
>  >   testSpecificAssumingCommonIsCalled();
>  > }
> 
> The only thing I would add to this is that /public void testXXX()/
> methods are called automatically by the framework.  So you need to
> call them something different if you don't want the framework to pick
> them up (which is what I think you are trying to avoid).
> 
> What Andrew may be implying here is to use a MethodTemplate
> (http://www.refactoring.com/catalog/formTemplateMethod.html).  So,
> define your BasicGetListTest as abstract.  Let the /testSpecific()/
> method be the only public test method which calls abstract methods for
> the testing.
> 
> I would modify Andrew's example to be this:
> 
> public void testSpecific() {
>     assertCommon(); //this is a private method on BasicGetListTest
>     assertSomethingElseWithFilters(); //this is abstract
> }

I have a different suggestion.

1. Write the first test, without worrying about the design.
2. Write another test.
3. Get them all passing.
4. Factor out all duplication among the tests.
5. Goto 2.

I find that when I am uncertain about the design, it works best to let 
the code tell /me/ what the design needs to be. After test #4, I usually 
have 90% of the framework I thought I needed. That usually turns out to 
be enough.
